sn47.5:1.3: “Rightly speaking, mendicants, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.
sn47.5:1.4: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.
sn47.5:1.6: The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
sn47.5:1.7: Rightly speaking, you’d call these five hindrances a ‘heap of the unskillful’.
sn47.5:1.8: For these five hindrances are entirely a heap of the unskillful.
sn47.5:2.1: Rightly speaking, you’d call these four kinds of mindfulness meditation a ‘heap of the skillful’.
sn47.5:2.2: For these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are entirely a heap of the skillful.
sn47.5:2.4: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.5:2.5: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
sn47.5:2.6: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …
sn47.5:2.7: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn47.5:2.8: Rightly speaking, you’d call these four kinds of mindfulness meditation a ‘heap of the skillful’.
sn47.5:2.9: For these four kinds of mindfulness meditation are entirely a heap of the skillful.”
